an7.52:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond.
an7.52:1.2: Then several lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
an7.52:1.3: “Sir, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
an7.52:1.4: It would be good if we got to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
an7.52:1.5: “Well then, reverends, come on the next sabbath day.
an7.52:1.6: Hopefully you’ll get to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
an7.52:1.7: “Yes, sir” they replied. Then they rose from their seats, bowed to Sāriputta, and respectfully circled him before leaving.
an7.52:2.1: Then on the next sabbath the lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, and stood to one side.
an7.52:2.2: Then they went together with Sāriputta to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to the Buddha:
an7.52:3.1: “Sir, could it be that someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,
an7.52:3.2: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
an7.52:3.5: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
an7.52:4.1: “Sāriputta, take the case of a someone who gives a gift as an investment, their mind tied to it, expecting to keep it, thinking ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.
an7.52:4.2: They give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
an7.52:4.3: What do you think, Sāriputta, don’t some people give gifts in this way?”
an7.52:5.1: “Sāriputta, someone who gives a gift as an investment,
an7.52:5.2: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of the Four Great Kings.
an7.52:5.3: When that deed, success, fame, and sovereignty is spent they return to this state of existence.
an7.52:6.1: Next, take the case of a someone who gives a gift not as an investment, their mind not tied to it, not expecting to keep it, and not thinking, ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.
an7.52:6.2: But they give a gift thinking, ‘It’s good to give’ …
an7.52:7.2: They give a gift thinking, ‘Giving was practiced by my father and my father’s father. It would not be right for me to abandon this family tradition.’ …
an7.52:8.2: They give a gift thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’ …
an7.52:9.2: They give a gift thinking, ‘The ancient brahmin seers were Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu.
an7.52:9.3: Just as they performed great sacrifices, I will share a gift.’ …
an7.52:10.3: They give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’ …
an7.52:11.1: They don’t give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’
an7.52:11.2: But they give a gift thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’
an7.52:11.3: They give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
an7.52:11.4: What do you think, Sāriputta, don’t some people give gifts in this way?”
an7.52:12.1: “Sāriputta, someone who gives gifts, not for any other reason,
an7.52:12.11: but thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind’,
an7.52:12.12: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn among the gods of Brahmā’s Host.
an7.52:12.13: When that deed, success, fame, and sovereignty is spent they are a non-returner; they do not return to this state of existence.
an7.52:13.1: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,
an7.52:13.2: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial.”
